original_text: In this article we consider an extension to the equations of poroelasticity by modelling the flow of a slightly compressible single phase fluid in a viscoelastic porous medium. The constitutive equations therefore allow for the presence of viscoelastic relaxation effects in the porous media (but not the fluid). Fully discrete numerical schemes are derived based on a lagged and non-lagged backward Euler time stepping method applied to a mixed and Galerkin finite element spatial discretization. We show that the lagged scheme is unconditionally stable and give an optimal a priori error bound for it. Furthermore, this scheme is practical and useful in the sense that it can be easily implemented in existing poroelasticity software because the coupling between the viscous stresses and pressures and the elasticity and flow equations is lagged by one time step. The required additional coding therefore takes the form of extra right hand side loads together with some updating subroutines for the viscoelastic internal variables, but the solver and assembly engines remain intact. This idea of lagging has been used before for nonlinearly viscoelastic diffusion problems in [3,24] but, of course, is not new. Lagging in numerical schemes is discussed more widely by Lowrie in [14].
original_translation: En este artículo consideramos una extensión a las ecuaciones de poroelasticidad al modelar el flujo de un fluido de fase única ligeramente compresible en un medio poroso viscoelástico. Las ecuaciones constitutivas permiten, por lo tanto, la presencia de efectos de relajación viscoelástica en los medios porosos (pero no en el fluido). Los esquemas numéricos completamente discretos se derivan basados en un método de paso de tiempo de Euler hacia atrás con rezago y sin rezago aplicado a una discretización espacial de elementos finitos mixtos y de Galerkin. Mostramos que el esquema rezagado es estable incondicionalmente y proporcionamos un límite de error a priori óptimo para él. Además, este esquema es práctico y útil en el sentido de que puede implementarse fácilmente en el software de poroelasticidad existente porque el acoplamiento entre las tensiones viscosas y las presiones y las ecuaciones de elasticidad y flujo se retrasa un paso de tiempo. El código adicional requerido toma la forma de cargas adicionales en el lado derecho junto con algunas subrutinas de actualización para las variables internas viscoelásticas, pero los motores de resolución y ensamblaje permanecen intactos. Esta idea de rezago ha sido utilizada antes para problemas de difusión viscoelástica no lineal en [3,24], pero, por supuesto, no es nueva. El rezago en esquemas numéricos es discutido más ampliamente por Lowrie en [14].

The constitutive equations therefore allow for the presence of viscoelastic relaxation effects in the porous media (but not the fluid).
Fully discrete numerical schemes are derived based on a lagged and non-lagged backward Euler time stepping method applied to a mixed and Galerkin finite element spatial discretization.
We show that the lagged scheme is unconditionally stable and give an optimal a priori error bound for it.

Furthermore, this scheme is practical and useful in the sense that it can be easily implemented in existing poroelasticity software because the coupling between the viscous stresses and pressures and the elasticity and flow equations is lagged by one time step.

The required additional coding therefore takes the form of extra right hand side loads together with some updating subroutines for the viscoelastic internal variables, but the solver and assembly engines remain intact.
This idea of lagging has been used before for nonlinearly viscoelastic diffusion problems in [3,24] but, of course, is not new.
Lagging in numerical schemes is discussed more widely by Lowrie in [14].

We show that the lagged scheme is unconditionally stable and give an optimal a priori error bound for it.

Furthermore, this scheme is practical and useful in the sense that it can be easily implemented in existing poroelasticity software because the coupling between the viscous stresses and pressures and the elasticity and flow equations is lagged by one time step.

The required additional coding therefore takes the form of extra right hand side loads together with some updating subroutines for the viscoelastic internal variables, but the solver and assembly engines remain intact.
This idea of lagging has been used before for nonlinearly viscoelastic diffusion problems in [3,24] but, of course, is not new.
Lagging in numerical schemes is discussed more widely by Lowrie in [14].

mixed and Galerkin finite element spatial discretization
.

.
mixed and Galerkin finite element spatia.translated_text:
En este artículo consideramos una extensión a las ecuaciones de poroelasticidad al modelar el flujo de un fluido de fase única ligeramente compresible en un medio poroso viscoelástico. Las ecuaciones constitutivas permiten, por lo tanto, la presencia de efectos de relajación viscoelástica en los medios porosos (pero no en el fluido). Output: Se derivan esquemas numéricos completamente discretos basados en un método de paso de tiempo de Euler hacia atrás con rezago y sin rezago aplicado a una
discretización espacial de elementos finitos mixtos y de Galerkin
. Mostramos que el esquema rezagado es estable incondicionalmente y proporcionamos un límite de error a priori óptimo para él. Además, este esquema es práctico y útil en el sentido de que puede implementarse fácilmente en el software de poroelasticidad existente porque el acoplamiento entre las tensiones viscosas y las presiones y las ecuaciones de elasticidad y flujo se retrasa un paso de tiempo. El código adicional requerido toma la forma de cargas adicionales en el lado derecho junto con algunas subrutinas de actualización para las variables internas viscoelásticas, pero los motores de resolución y ensamblaje permanecen intactos. Esta idea de rezago ha sido utilizada antes para problemas de difusión viscoelástica no lineal en [3,24], pero, por supuesto, no es nueva. El rezago en esquemas numéricos es discutido más ampliamente por Lowrie en [14].

modelling the flow of a slightly compres.translated_key: modelar el flujo de un fluido de fase única ligeramente compresible en un medio poroso viscoelástico
original_annotated_sentences:
In this article we consider an extension to the equations of poroelasticity by
modelling the flow of a slightly compressible single phase fluid in a viscoelastic porous medium
.
The constitutive equations therefore allow for the presence of viscoelastic relaxation effects in the porous media (but not the fluid).
Fully discrete numerical schemes are derived based on a lagged and non-lagged backward Euler time stepping method applied to a mixed and Galerkin finite element spatial discretization.
We show that the lagged scheme is unconditionally stable and give an optimal a priori error bound for it.

Furthermore, this scheme is practical and useful in the sense that it can be easily implemented in existing poroelasticity software because the coupling between the viscous stresses and pressures and the elasticity and flow equations is lagged by one time step.

The required additional coding therefore takes the form of extra right hand side loads together with some updating subroutines for the viscoelastic internal variables, but the solver and assembly engines remain intact.
This idea of lagging has been used before for nonlinearly viscoelastic diffusion problems in [3,24] but, of course, is not new.
Lagging in numerical schemes is discussed more widely by Lowrie in [14].

.
